intro:
This is suppose to be a public account :) 
Hoping to make friends with privacy enthusiasts and others alike  

Being on my "following" list does not imply endorsement, though being on my "mute" list implies dis-endorsement™

Finally found my old acc :3

Just some useful links that I keep for myself~

---
#### Utilities

[Markdown Cheat Sheet](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:markdown  "simple guide on how to use style text")
[ZeroPolls](http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroPolls.bit/?Home "Need to make some polls?")
[Mother Of All Block List](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LgqZfbtr6dukbjHdjWBEmmthq1shEv3y1/ "easy enough to understand, helps block site, people that are harmful or untrustworthy")

---
#### Hubs

[Kaffie Hub](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv "~10MB of storage space, much better than default 50Kb of most hubs when you're posting a lot")
[Innocent Hubs](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1J1epG5eMc4bsmh69UctBg4PHEe5B3kYHY/hubs.html "A better, well maintained hub lists")
[Get All Hubs](http://127.0.0.1:43110/0hub.bit/ "An ancient, abandoned hublist")

---
#### Others

[ZeroNet vs Media](http://localhost:43110/1NEwsvyrAoEWU64ZozwdfgEUQhwxiCrh1t "ZeroNet in the eyes of the media #timeline")

##How to disagree productively and find common ground - Julia Dhar
>Some days, it feels like the only thing we can agree on is that we can't agree -- on anything. Drawing on her background as a world debate champion, Julia Dhar offers three techniques to reshape the way we talk to each other so we can start disagreeing productively and finding common ground -- over family dinners, during work meetings and in our national conversations.
>> Link: [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=phgjouv0BUA&t=3s&index=44&list=WL "The cleanet that many despise T_T")

tldw/ (another version of tldr):
>The talk is basically about avoiding attacking the person giving the argument, find common ground, and keep in mind you might be wrong. 
>All to make controversies more digestible and more productive at finding solutions.

Welcome people of the world :0

I don't know much about how 0net work but this seems like a problem that might worth a look. 

> ##How to create a long-term persistent Zeronet?

>One of the areas zeronet could be improved is that each item is currently unique by default.
>That means (hash-)identical items cannot be identified and commonly shared, even among merger-sites.

>That leads to a fragile state of optional files in case not everyone shares all of the items of a big site default.

>An example that illustrates the above would be a shared picture (or other informational item), which the original author might decide to deleted and therefore disappears the very moment that decision to delete the item spreads via "sign&publish".

more at [IFS Blog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Cd1SqtZUUpK8e8KUUqBttHzwPfbG1CU6y/?Post:2:How+to+create+a+long-term+persistent+Zeronet+)

Ps - I'd like to understand more about the "sign&publish" if anyone have time to explain :)

Pss - Also would items be deleted via "sign&publish" would work best when the author actually wanted to delete completely for example a post? And not let others keep seeding it?
SPACEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE... (until this fills the universe)

The story: A [Reddit Post](https://www.reddit.com/r/zeronet/comments/33uk59/presentation_about_how_does_zeronet_works/) explaining [how ZeroNet works (powerpoint)](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1_2qK1IuOKJ51pgBvllZ9Yu7Au2l551t3XBgyTSvilew/pub?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000&slide=id.g9a1cce9ee_0_9)

I was wondering about **No single point of failure** 
> There is still single point failure because the person who created the site still have full control of it (which is good but that means if someone aka a government wanted to take down certain site they could target the creator)
> I think that's also how [GetGames](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Games5166ST5jGdtEnrD8xHk7nUcBBWjR/) got taken down

Any other opinion or suggestions?

I've came across a quite interesting book in my opinion. I know it was published in 2014 but as the title said, truly beautiful~ <3

---
Taking infographics and data-visualisation to the next level, this rich 256-page book visualises captivating and intriguing patterns and connections across art, science, health and pop.

Covering everything from dog breeds and movie plots to timelines of the far future and the complexity of relationships of the Middle East, this stunning book unveils the intricate, invisible and sometimes hilarious stories lurking in the data, information & knowledge surrounding us. 

---
[OriginalWebsite](https://informationisbeautiful.net/books/) (ClearWeb)

ps: throw me an email if you want a copy, I really encourage you to go out and support the author but if it's not accessible go ahead :3

*Day: About 59 Earth days.*
*Diameter: About 3,000, less than half of Earth's.*

> *Day: About 243 Earth days.*
> *Average diameter: About 7,500 miles, almost as large as Earth.*

@Znnex: not really, the immigration issue is just being blown up by Trump's campaign, it's actually have fallen to an all time low already and also theres something called "[Circular Flow/Wikipedia/CleanWeb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_migration)" so if you secure the border, people are more likely to overstay their visas and become an illegal immigrant.

@Bigbadbob: Btw just curious but do you think it's normal to reference politicians view point in our reasoning? To me it seems like choosing a soft ground to stand our argument on, easy and effortless to do but not as firm as normal hard and concrete facts / statistics. Referencing is less confusing and harder to get off track so got that going for it, idk, guess we human likes stories afterall. :p

@caryoscelus: hehe~ look forward to that >:)
@caryoscelus: well could be fun to try, still you'd have to have time for it tho which probably will be a problem. :X
